main event: Two soldiers at Fort Bliss, Texas observed an unidentified aerial object on March 6, 1950 at 0645 hours. The object was very slow-moving, observed for 20-30 seconds at an elevation of approximately 60°, and appeared to be light or silver in color.
interesting points: The object was observed at a very slow speed for 20-30 seconds at an elevation of 60°, with no sound or odor accompanying it.
The object was visible by reflection and appeared to be the size of a star, with its shape not discernible.
It was observed in the southwest direction, moving north, and faded out of sight after 40-60 seconds.
The observers were considered intelligent, trustworthy, and of good character with no indication of altered vision at the time of sighting.

The report includes a guide to investigation, requesting details on radar sightings, local weather conditions, and the collection of soil samples, photographs, and statements if the object contacted the earth.
